Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Autonomous functionality for HullBUG Underwater Hull Grooming System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project and the associated environmental benefits forthcoming from the successful research effort is immense. With 50,000 ships operating on the world?s ocean every day, and 1 Giga Tons of Green House Gases emitted every year by the global fleet, a 5-15% improvement in fuel economy through improved hull efficiency resulting from proactive grooming is staggering. With a 5% improvement in hull efficiency the fleet fuel usage will be reduced 15 Million Tons, leading to $9 Billion in fuel cost savings, while reducing Green House Gases by 45 Million Tons per year! Additionally the transport of Aquatic Invasive Species from port to port will be dramatically reduced. Successful development of an autonomous hull grooming system will stimulate proactive grooming leading to a $Billion commercial market.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project, Autonomous functionality for Underwater Hull Grooming System, seeks to develop, test, and implement the situation awareness sensors, navigation system, and supporting algorithms required for fully autonomous hull cleaning operations for proactive grooming of ship hulls. Difficulties associated with 6 degree of freedom navigation on steel ship hulls with their intrinsic magnetic field anomalies, in highly turbid water (zero visibility) is considerably. Cost effective obstacle detection and hull feature identification must be organic to the system to allow obstacle avoidance behaviors and along hull navigation fixes based on feature recognition. To aid the system a novel approach to Ultra Short Baseline Acoustic positioning will be developed, as acoustic navigation in the severe multipath environment found in close proximity along a ship hull poses significant challenges as well. Solutions to these challenges will

allow a proactive grooming robot to negotiate the complexities of the hull and provide an accurate coverage model for the ship grooming operation. The required periodicity of proactive grooming will allow for the addition of inspection sensors, inspection data mapping and change detection to further improve ship hull maintenance and efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results of our Phase I effort have provided a roadmap for Phase II efforts which will lead to an autonomous hull cleaning system. Through the evaluation and test of various sensors we have identified the sensor compliment required to support an innovative hull referenced positioning system. This approach will enable the navigation methodology supportive of full coverage cleaning and accurately referenced hull inspection data. Additionally, a data fusion algorithm has been defined to enable a pose graph representation of the HullBUG, a hull crawling system, enabling a feature based localization system to provide accurate position estimates. A novel method of sensor data correlation allows the system to execute long missions with bounded position error.

The selected sensors were tested in simulated operational environments with better than anticipated results. IMU/AHRS sensors were tested in high vibration environments over mission appropriate durations, with simulated vehicle motion. The suggested sensor compliment will provide a robust suite of traditional and untraditional navigation sensors. Acoustic position aides and acoustic communication systems showed adequate promise for incorporation to complete the sensing suite.

A novel analytical approach encompassing data fusion, feature based navigation, and silultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) techniques implemented with a highly efficient computational algorithm will enable autonomous navigation on the hull. The data registration accuracy afforded through this approach supports the requirements associated with underwater inspection in lieu of dry docking (UWILD).

In addition to advancing the state of the art in autonomous navigation in a feature devoid environment, autonomous cleaning of ship hulls has enormous financial and environmental benefits. Keeping hulls clean has been known to improve ship efficiency for many years. The difficulties associated with maintaining a bio-fouling free ship hull, however, are numerous.  In the past, bio-toxic materials were sued to coat the hull. Tin and copper were used extensively to reduce bio fouling. Although effective, these coatings leach into harbors damaging the eco system in the ports and have been or are being phased out.  The result is inefficient hulls which waste enormous amounts of fuel. The wasted fuel is expensive and damaging to the environment. An estimated 5-10% fuel savings can be realized when operating with clean hulls. The cost savings are substantial, however, the reduction in green house gases (GHG) emitted by the shipping industry is just as large. Infrequent hull cleaning due to inefficient and dangerous diver based methods, and tethered remotely operated vehicle are currently the norm.

Autonomous/highly automated frequent hull cleaning performed by HullBUG will solve these problems with the associated immense financial and environmental benefits.
